treasury_media.title: Uitzending - ZOEK HET UIT! Enzymen
treasury_media.description: Een nieuwe aflevering van de Klokhuisserie 'Zoek Het Uit!'; een serie over wetenschappelijk onderzoek in Nederland. Enzymen spelen een belangrijke rol bij de spijsvertering. Ze 'knippen' het voedsel in hapklare brokken die opgenomen kunnen worden door...

treasury_media.title: Vastgoed voor Iconen - DuPont Leiden
treasury_media.description: DuPont Industrial Biosciences is een wereldleider in industriële biotechnologie. Dat betekent dat het bedrijf dagelijks op zoek is naar de beste wetenschappelijke oplossingen voor 's werelds grootste uitdagingen. Om dat mogelijk te maken, moet iedere...

company.name: University of Amsterdam & Unilever Research Laboratory

profile_positions.company: University of Amsterdam & Unilever Research Laboratory
profile_positions.description:
Prevention of Food Spoilage (PBTS project) 
It is estimated that the world loses or wastes nearly a third of the food produced for human consumption. Food spoilage mostly results from microbial contamination. Preserving food and extending its shelf life is usually accomplished by preventing these microbes to grow. However microbes can evolve to resist antimicrobial strategies. This project identified how fungal cells respond to antifungal compounds. Global transcriptomic and proteomic studies identified responsible signal transduction pathways involved in cells sensing and resisting antifungals. The project was funded by Unilever and performed at the University of Amsterdam (Institute for Molecular Cell Biology) in collaboration with various international research teams. Results were published in 11 peer-reviewed papers and book chapters.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description: Every living organism continuously senses it surroundings to find food, avoid predators and check out mates. Picking up signals and responding appropriately to them is essential for survival. Sexual interaction by yeast cells is studied as a model system for signal transduction. This study particularly focused on sexual agglutinins - molecules that are produced in response to hormones from potential mates and that enable the different mating types to adhere specifically to their partner prior to cell fusion. The results were published in 5 peer-reviewed papers.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher
